content: The Bitcoin Bubble II: Pricing BTC Pascal Bedard Blocked Unblock Follow Following Dec 9, 2017 In my post “ The Bitcoin Bubble ” I explain the logic behind pricing btc relative to the usd. That post created quite a stir, with some people sending me mails to either tell me I’m crazy OR to tell me “it all makes sense” even if the 100k usd per btc seems ridiculous (even to me!). Please take the time to read in full that post, as it is the back bone and starting point for this one and provides the necessary discussion and caveats. Btc could be “as good as gold” which could bring it to as much as half a million OR, even without “gold status”, it could move quite easily to close to 100k usd… read on for details… Again, “opinions” don’t matter, including my own. What matters to make sense of the crypto phenomenon is to at least have some kind of logical framework to evaluate the prices of cryptos between them and relative to standard currencies such as the usd or cad. Lets look at various scenarios to add to the framework of btc valuation as we started doing in the initial post, and add a more explicit discussion about the risks to these scenarios, as well as more precise calculations. Valuation of assets in uncharted territory First lets state the obvious: we don’t know how to value cryptos, because it’s totally uncharted territory, they do not pertain to a “piece of property” of capital like stock nor are they a claim on future income in the form of debt, such as corporate or government bonds or mortgage debt. A typical valuation for a company might look at future possible profits, which would include scale possibilities, competition, how “fundamental” the new company is in terms of innovation and new products that “change the game” and the genius of the management and the strategic position now and going forward of the company and its products. A few examples of companies that came up with “game changers” are Ford’s Model T, Microsoft’s “Windows”, Apple’s Iphone and MacBook, Facebook, Uber, Netflix, and AirBnB. The list is extremely long — we could write a book only on this fascinating subject. For debt pricing, the interest rate is related to the relative availability of credit in the market (if available loanable funds are scarce, there is more “fighting for credit” between credit demanders) and competition in the credit supplier market (if I am the only one supplying credit, I can charge you a very high interest rate). On top of these basic valuation considerations, there are risks to consider . For instance, inflation takes away purchasing power of nominal amounts of money received in the future. You might also never see your money again, because of defaults or bankruptcies. If you put your money in other currencies, you are also exposed to “ exchange rate risk ”: I put 100 usd in Japan for investments, and the Yen crashes relative to the usd, which means whatever Yen I have are worth less than before when expressed in usd. How could we put a “value” on crypto currencies? The only reasonable way to do this is to “guesstimate” how much money (expressed in usd) parked in OTHER asset classes will flock TO cryptos in general. Then you add details crypto by crypto. But as I explain in my initial post, btc is “special” in this matter, because it has the leader advantage, and THAT has made it the most easily and widely convertible to usd, the most trusted and traded, and THAT is absolutely fundamental to the entire project. This has positioned btc as the “central pillar” of the entire crypto world, because OTHER cryptos are generally convertible to btc, and btc is convertible to usd . For example, I personally think “eth” (Ether, associated to the Ethereum blockchain) has considerably more usability, scalability, and innovative potential for society as whole, as is also the case for Ripple and a few others. But “usefulness” is NOT a core building block of a good store of value… a good store of value must not degrade, must have limited supply, and be readily convertible to a very useful currency (typically the usd). That is the central difference between btc and most others: btc is readily convertible to usd. The second most “easily convertible” crypto directly to usd is Ethereum, and indeed it also has a solid pricing, but nothing near btc valuation. Before we continue, here are the top 10 cryptos and their approximate respective market shares in % of the approximately 415 billion dollar market capitalization of the total crypto currency market: Bitcoin (btc), 60% Ethereum (eth), 10% Bitcoin Cash (bch), 5% Iota (miota), 3% Ripple (xrp), 3% Litecoin (ltc), 2% Dash (dash), 1% Nem (xem), 1% Monero (xmr), 1% Bitcoin Gold (btg), 1% Using conservative estimates, total crypto market value is about 415 billion, while total value of stocks + bonds + gold is about 180 trillion, and that is a VERY conservative estimate. This means official asset classes (not counting real estate, land, art, silver, and a few others) is a bit more than 400 times bigger than the entire crypto market. As I explain in my first post on this Bitcoin thing, I think the best way to estimate pricing of cryptos is to get an idea of how much money wants to “park” in crypto assets in general, then in each crypto currency specifically. Scenarios and Risks for Pricing the Bitcoin Scenario 0$ It is possible that the value of btc plunges to zero (or close to zero) at one point. As far as I can tell, the possible causes of btc crashing to zero would be: Widespread fraud that causes a breach in the “trustability” of the btc and associated blockchain, and more importantly the players in the market, like the major exchanges and so on. Fraud can come from several sources, but mostly 3 main sources: 1) hackings that gain access to the “private keys” of holders of btc and other cryptos, which enables the hackers to send the hacked btc content associated to those wallets to themselves, then selling off the whole thing against usd and walking away with a good loot. This has happened on several occasions but still remains rare relative to the size of the market. The second potential cause for total collapse is 2) fraud coming from “crypto brokers” such as Coinbase, with too many bad experiences, bad customer service, or outright theft, causing a breakdown of trust. This has not yet happened on a broad scale, although customer service and transparency are indeed left wanting in this sphere for now. The third major potential cause for crypto fraud is 3) “fake cryptos” on parallel blockchains that pretend to be the btc blockchain and somehow get enough collaborators to make people confused about what is a true btc and what is a “counterfeit” btc. In ALL cases, the ultimate killer is a breakdown of trust . I do not see this as a high probability outcome, but it is a possible outcome nonetheless. Concerted and generalized war on btc and other cryptos by major states . This would happen due to difficulty of regulation and other blockchain and crypto control issues. Not just China, but ALL major countries, and especially the USA. This would cause a fracture of one essential item making btc an interesting asset for the foreseeable future and giving it the “gold standard” position within the rising crypto world: convertibility to usd . If convertibility to usd is lost, the value of most cryptos will fall to close to zero, because more than 99%+ of “real world transactions” are in standard currencies, and convertibility to usd and/or major currencies is key to any asset class. I also do not see this as a high probability outcome, because there are growing numbers of institutional players, futures markets and btc derivatives, and organized and regulated exchanges that deal with cryptos (especially btc), along with some transactions being done in the various cryptos. A major selloff by initial holders . This could cause the price to crash due to the relatively shallow depth of the btc market (it does not take “that much” sell or buy activity to move the price, compared to major currencies or major bond markets, for example). A big selloff is possible, but I am not sure this is high probability, because why sell all your high-value assets that are gaining value and are a great store of value? In fact, it is mostly the 2 other points above that would trigger this 3rd one, and I do not see this as a probable outcome. This does not mean initial holders of btc won’t sell some of their assets to get income… but that is a manageable “mini shock” for btc. Btc currently has almost 400 000 transactions per day (and growing rapidly), has growing government regulation (hence acceptance), has rapidly growing interest by “Big Money” such as banks, hedge funds, and major fund managers, is solving scalability problems a bit more every passing week, and now has official futures trading by big institutional players . Criminal money in btc is losing importance relative to “legal” money. The Ethereum blockchain handles MORE transactions per day than btc and has a LOT of “real world potential”, as does Ripple, whose technology was recently adopted by giants like American Express and Santander . Does this sound like cryptos and blockchains are a passing fad that will all just go away any time soon? No. Given the facts, I will thus posit for the remainder of this text that 1) cryptos are there to stay and 2) btc has a leader advantage , simply because it was the first and is the most easily and widely convertible to major currencies. Scenario 1000$ One possibility for the price of btc is that it attracted a disproportionate amount of interest relative to its true usefulness and intrinsic value. This would suggest that the “number 2 crypto currency” has a more realistic pricing, which is the price of Ethereum, roughly 600$-700$ (the current price). Given that eth may be underpriced and btc may be overpriced (I am not saying this is the case), we would have a price for Ethereum of at least 1000$. That would imply that 1) the net influx of capital flocking FROM standard asset classes like stocks and bonds TO crypto assets would all go to non-btc cryptos AND 2) currently parked funds in btc would go towards the other crypto assets, thus causing a general upward shift of non-btc prices such as Ethereum and a severe downward shift of btc. This would be a 95% price drop. This would cause general panic about crypto assets and a widespread run for the exits regarding that asset class, perhaps crashing the price towards zero, at least for a while. To me, this is the highest risk scenario on btc in terms of its probability of occurrence: 1) a widespread selloff of btc to buy other cryptos and 2) all new “outside money” (from more classic asset classes) going TO cryptos to be concentrated in non-btc assets such as Ethereum. This is possible, but I doubt it is likely to happen as long as the social norm of btc being the “central pillar” of cryptos for liquidity and convertibility remains intact. Scenario 74 000$ A more realistic estimation of global wealth currently parked in non-crypto assets includes all of the following: Stocks: 100 trillion. Credit and related markets: 150 trillion. Gold and silver: 10 trillion. Undeclared criminal wealth: 4 trillion. Lets just take a round number of 250 trillion to base our calculations. Current usd value of btc is about 250 billion, which is 0,1% of the total estimation for the major asset classes (250 trillion). We thus currently have about 0.1% of global wealth parked in btc, and a bit less than 0.2% of global wealth parked all crypto currencies combined. A total selloff of the top 10 cryptos is unlikely for now and for the foreseeable future (unless one of the main risks materialize), because the emergence of cryptos and blockchain is a bit like the emergence of Internet in the 1990s: even with the “dot com crash” of the early 2000s, you did not have an overnight abandonment of all Internet and the Web. It’s “structural” and not related to corporate profits or even the economic outlook, which can change dramatically within one year when a crisis hits. Based on this and seeing growing interest and momentum of cryptos and blochchain,it seems possible that 1% of all global wealth could eventually flock to cryptos, especially with currently high asset prices and low expected returns… If we suppose that btc share of cryptos falls from 60% to 50% and the other 10% is gained by others, we would have 50% of 1% of total world wealth going towards btc in the next few years. Since current and near-future btc global supply is about 17 million (the maximum is 21 million but will not be reached for a while), we get the following valuation, for 50% of 1% of total wealth flocking to 17 million btc: 0.5*0.01*250 trillion / 17 million = 74 000$ (approx). Note that there seems to me a great deal of demand for assets available to park wealth, with real estate markets becoming more and more like stock markets and Asian savings seeking to park in safe assets . Given this, the estimate of global wealth looking for a place to park is probably severely underestimated at 250 trillion, so 74k usd per btc is very conservative. Scenario 148 000$ and 370 000$ This is the very same story as the preceding one, but with 2% and 5% respectively of global wealth going to crypto assets. Scenario “as good as gold” 400 000$ There are about 6 billion ounces of gold in circulation. M1 usd money supply is about 3500 billion usd, M2 usd money supply is about 13 000 billion. Based on these 2 most-common and referenced money supply measures and using a naïve (and somewhat over simplified) extrapolation, the price of gold “should” be: 3500/6 = 583 usd (using M1). 13000/6 = 2167 usd (using M2). The current price of gold is roughly 1300 usd, so the price is between the M1 and M2 implied prices, since the average of the 2 prices is 1375$. Supposing btc gains traction as a legal, liquid, safe, limited supply asset that stores value and serves as central pillar of a new crypto market destined to rise tremendously, we would get a “gold standard” price. Using the same pricing as above for gold and using the maximum possible btc supply, we would get the following conservative estimates: 3500 billion / 21 million = 167 000$ (using M1). 13000 billion / 21 million = 619 000$ (using M2). Using the same average price as we got for gold (approx), we get 393 000$, so roughly 400 000$. This evaluation underestimates the potential price with this method, because btc has a fixed maximum limit, and usd money supply is always increasing, and all this is typically at least a bit priced into market prices at any given time. This valuation seems on the high side to me, but I can’t really say it’s necessarily wrong. Conclusion One possible scenario is that all governments eliminate the fiat currency system, take on a national crypto currency system, and ban btc and most other cryptos. Knowing how slow large states move and how inefficient are, and seeing how btc and the others are gaining market momentum, I see this as low probability for the coming few years. Given this, there are a few potential scenarios to ponder: A general selloff of all cryptos, crashing the price to zero. A general selloff of btc to go towards other cryptos, thus crashing the price of btc. Not likely due to the “leader advantage”, convertibility to usd, and widespread and growing use of btc. 1% of global wealth parks in cryptos and 50% of that goes to btc, giving a price of 74k usd as a conservative lower bound. 2% of global wealth parks in cryptos and 50% of that goes to btc, giving a price of 148k usd. 3% of global wealth parks in cryptos and 50% of that goes to btc, giving a price of 222k usd. 4% of global wealth parks in cryptos and 50% of that goes to btc, giving a price of 296k usd. 5% of global wealth parks in cryptos and 50% of that goes to btc, giving a price of 370k usd. The price of btc becomes similar to the price of gold due to “reference and refuge currency” status, giving an approximate price of 400k usd. What to make of all this? Well, if I disregard my analysis, I find prices of 74k+ usd per btc totally unrealistic! But at the same time, the general logic is there and I have yet to get one logic-based explanation of why it “should” be otherwise. I don’t know what to say… If the market holds and crypto/blockchain technology rises as an important new building block for the economy of the future, it is indeed quite possible to see btc prices hover well above 100k, with even more stratospheric potential. Again, this is based on assumptions. If these assumptions hold, 100k+ usd per btc is strangely a “realistic” pricing… I know it seems weird… I feel the same way! Clap, like, share, and comment! And please read Part I ! Feel free to send questions or comments to me by email. Regards. Pascal Bedard pbedard@yourpersonaleconomist.com
title_html: The Bitcoin Bubble II: Pricing BTC

The Bitcoin Bubble II: Pricing BTC

Pascal Bedard
Dec 9, 2017

In my post “The Bitcoin Bubble” I explain the logic behind pricing btc relative to the usd. That post created quite a stir, with some people sending me mails to either tell me I’m crazy OR to tell me “it all makes sense” even if the 100k usd per btc seems ridiculous (even to me!). Please take the time to read in full that post, as it is the back bone and starting point for this one and provides the necessary discussion and caveats. Btc could be “as good as gold” which could bring it to as much as half a million OR, even without “gold status”, it could move quite easily to close to 100k usd… read on for details…

Again, “opinions” don’t matter, including my own. What matters to make sense of the crypto phenomenon is to at least have some kind of logical framework to evaluate the prices of cryptos between them and relative to standard currencies such as the usd or cad.

Lets look at various scenarios to add to the framework of btc valuation as we started doing in the initial post, and add a more explicit discussion about the risks to these scenarios, as well as more precise calculations.

Valuation of assets in uncharted territory

First lets state the obvious: we don’t know how to value cryptos, because it’s totally uncharted territory, they do not pertain to a “piece of property” of capital like stock nor are they a claim on future income in the form of debt, such as corporate or government bonds or mortgage debt.

A typical valuation for a company might look at future possible profits, which would include scale possibilities, competition, how “fundamental” the new company is in terms of innovation and new products that “change the game” and the genius of the management and the strategic position now and going forward of the company and its products. A few examples of companies that came up with “game changers” are Ford’s Model T, Microsoft’s “Windows”, Apple’s Iphone and MacBook, Facebook, Uber, Netflix, and AirBnB. The list is extremely long — we could write a book only on this fascinating subject.

For debt pricing, the interest rate is related to the relative availability of credit in the market (if available loanable funds are scarce, there is more “fighting for credit” between credit demanders) and competition in the credit supplier market (if I am the only one supplying credit, I can charge you a very high interest rate).

On top of these basic valuation considerations, there are risks to consider. For instance, inflation takes away purchasing power of nominal amounts of money received in the future. You might also never see your money again, because of defaults or bankruptcies. If you put your money in other currencies, you are also exposed to “exchange rate risk”: I put 100 usd in Japan for investments, and the Yen crashes relative to the usd, which means whatever Yen I have are worth less than before when expressed in usd.

How could we put a “value” on crypto currencies? The only reasonable way to do this is to “guesstimate” how much money (expressed in usd) parked in OTHER asset classes will flock TO cryptos in general. Then you add details crypto by crypto.

But as I explain in my initial post, btc is “special” in this matter, because it has the leader advantage, and THAT has made it the most easily and widely convertible to usd, the most trusted and traded, and THAT is absolutely fundamental to the entire project. This has positioned btc as the “central pillar” of the entire crypto world, because OTHER cryptos are generally convertible to btc, and btc is convertible to usd.

For example, I personally think “eth” (Ether, associated to the Ethereum blockchain) has considerably more usability, scalability, and innovative potential for society as whole, as is also the case for Ripple and a few others.

But “usefulness” is NOT a core building block of a good store of value… a good store of value must not degrade, must have limited supply, and be readily convertible to a very useful currency (typically the usd). That is the central difference between btc and most others: btc is readily convertible to usd. The second most “easily convertible” crypto directly to usd is Ethereum, and indeed it also has a solid pricing, but nothing near btc valuation.

Before we continue, here are the top 10 cryptos and their approximate respective market shares in % of the approximately 415 billion dollar market capitalization of the total crypto currency market:

Bitcoin (btc), 60%

Ethereum (eth), 10%

Bitcoin Cash (bch), 5%

Iota (miota), 3%

Ripple (xrp), 3%

Litecoin (ltc), 2%

Dash (dash), 1%

Nem (xem), 1%

Monero (xmr), 1%

Bitcoin Gold (btg), 1%

Using conservative estimates, total crypto market value is about 415 billion, while total value of stocks + bonds + gold is about 180 trillion, and that is a VERY conservative estimate. This means official asset classes (not counting real estate, land, art, silver, and a few others) is a bit more than 400 times bigger than the entire crypto market. As I explain in my first post on this Bitcoin thing, I think the best way to estimate pricing of cryptos is to get an idea of how much money wants to “park” in crypto assets in general, then in each crypto currency specifically.

Scenarios and Risks for Pricing the Bitcoin

Scenario 0$

It is possible that the value of btc plunges to zero (or close to zero) at one point. As far as I can tell, the possible causes of btc crashing to zero would be:

  1. Widespread fraud that causes a breach in the “trustability” of the btc and associated blockchain, and more importantly the players in the market, like the major exchanges and so on. Fraud can come from several sources, but mostly 3 main sources: 1) hackings that gain access to the “private keys” of holders of btc and other cryptos, which enables the hackers to send the hacked btc content associated to those wallets to themselves, then selling off the whole thing against usd and walking away with a good loot. This has happened on several occasions but still remains rare relative to the size of the market. The second potential cause for total collapse is 2) fraud coming from “crypto brokers” such as Coinbase, with too many bad experiences, bad customer service, or outright theft, causing a breakdown of trust. This has not yet happened on a broad scale, although customer service and transparency are indeed left wanting in this sphere for now. The third major potential cause for crypto fraud is 3) “fake cryptos” on parallel blockchains that pretend to be the btc blockchain and somehow get enough collaborators to make people confused about what is a true btc and what is a “counterfeit” btc. In ALL cases, the ultimate killer is a breakdown of trust. I do not see this as a high probability outcome, but it is a possible outcome nonetheless.
  2. Concerted and generalized war on btc and other cryptos by major states. This would happen due to difficulty of regulation and other blockchain and crypto control issues. Not just China, but ALL major countries, and especially the USA. This would cause a fracture of one essential item making btc an interesting asset for the foreseeable future and giving it the “gold standard” position within the rising crypto world: convertibility to usd. If convertibility to usd is lost, the value of most cryptos will fall to close to zero, because more than 99%+ of “real world transactions” are in standard currencies, and convertibility to usd and/or major currencies is key to any asset class. I also do not see this as a high probability outcome, because there are growing numbers of institutional players, futures markets and btc derivatives, and organized and regulated exchanges that deal with cryptos (especially btc), along with some transactions being done in the various cryptos.
  3. A major selloff by initial holders. This could cause the price to crash due to the relatively shallow depth of the btc market (it does not take “that much” sell or buy activity to move the price, compared to major currencies or major bond markets, for example). A big selloff is possible, but I am not sure this is high probability, because why sell all your high-value assets that are gaining value and are a great store of value? In fact, it is mostly the 2 other points above that would trigger this 3rd one, and I do not see this as a probable outcome. This does not mean initial holders of btc won’t sell some of their assets to get income… but that is a manageable “mini shock” for btc.

Btc currently has almost 400 000 transactions per day (and growing rapidly), has growing government regulation (hence acceptance), has rapidly growing interest by “Big Money” such as banks, hedge funds, and major fund managers, is solving scalability problems a bit more every passing week, and now has official futures trading by big institutional players. Criminal money in btc is losing importance relative to “legal” money. The Ethereum blockchain handles MORE transactions per day than btc and has a LOT of “real world potential”, as does Ripple, whose technology was recently adopted by giants like American Express and Santander. Does this sound like cryptos and blockchains are a passing fad that will all just go away any time soon? No.

Given the facts, I will thus posit for the remainder of this text that 1) cryptos are there to stay and 2) btc has a leader advantage, simply because it was the first and is the most easily and widely convertible to major currencies.

Scenario 1000$

One possibility for the price of btc is that it attracted a disproportionate amount of interest relative to its true usefulness and intrinsic value. This would suggest that the “number 2 crypto currency” has a more realistic pricing, which is the price of Ethereum, roughly 600$-700$ (the current price). Given that eth may be underpriced and btc may be overpriced (I am not saying this is the case), we would have a price for Ethereum of at least 1000$.

That would imply that 1) the net influx of capital flocking FROM standard asset classes like stocks and bonds TO crypto assets would all go to non-btc cryptos AND 2) currently parked funds in btc would go towards the other crypto assets, thus causing a general upward shift of non-btc prices such as Ethereum and a severe downward shift of btc.

This would be a 95% price drop. This would cause general panic about crypto assets and a widespread run for the exits regarding that asset class, perhaps crashing the price towards zero, at least for a while.

To me, this is the highest risk scenario on btc in terms of its probability of occurrence: 1) a widespread selloff of btc to buy other cryptos and 2) all new “outside money” (from more classic asset classes) going TO cryptos to be concentrated in non-btc assets such as Ethereum. This is possible, but I doubt it is likely to happen as long as the social norm of btc being the “central pillar” of cryptos for liquidity and convertibility remains intact.

Scenario 74 000$

A more realistic estimation of global wealth currently parked in non-crypto assets includes all of the following:

  1. Stocks: 100 trillion.
  2. Credit and related markets: 150 trillion.
  3. Gold and silver: 10 trillion.
  4. Undeclared criminal wealth: 4 trillion.

Lets just take a round number of 250 trillion to base our calculations.

Current usd value of btc is about 250 billion, which is 0,1% of the total estimation for the major asset classes (250 trillion). We thus currently have about 0.1% of global wealth parked in btc, and a bit less than 0.2% of global wealth parked all crypto currencies combined.

A total selloff of the top 10 cryptos is unlikely for now and for the foreseeable future (unless one of the main risks materialize), because the emergence of cryptos and blockchain is a bit like the emergence of Internet in the 1990s: even with the “dot com crash” of the early 2000s, you did not have an overnight abandonment of all Internet and the Web. It’s “structural” and not related to corporate profits or even the economic outlook, which can change dramatically within one year when a crisis hits.

Based on this and seeing growing interest and momentum of cryptos and blochchain,it seems possible that 1% of all global wealth could eventually flock to cryptos, especially with currently high asset prices and low expected returns… If we suppose that btc share of cryptos falls from 60% to 50% and the other 10% is gained by others, we would have 50% of 1% of total world wealth going towards btc in the next few years. Since current and near-future btc global supply is about 17 million (the maximum is 21 million but will not be reached for a while), we get the following valuation, for 50% of 1% of total wealth flocking to 17 million btc:

0.5*0.01*250 trillion / 17 million = 74 000$ (approx).

Note that there seems to me a great deal of demand for assets available to park wealth, with real estate markets becoming more and more like stock markets and Asian savings seeking to park in safe assets. Given this, the estimate of global wealth looking for a place to park is probably severely underestimated at 250 trillion, so 74k usd per btc is very conservative.

Scenario 148 000$ and 370 000$

This is the very same story as the preceding one, but with 2% and 5% respectively of global wealth going to crypto assets.

Scenario “as good as gold” 400 000$

There are about 6 billion ounces of gold in circulation. M1 usd money supply is about 3500 billion usd, M2 usd money supply is about 13 000 billion. Based on these 2 most-common and referenced money supply measures and using a naïve (and somewhat over simplified) extrapolation, the price of gold “should” be:

3500/6 = 583 usd (using M1).

13000/6 = 2167 usd (using M2).

The current price of gold is roughly 1300 usd, so the price is between the M1 and M2 implied prices, since the average of the 2 prices is 1375$.

Supposing btc gains traction as a legal, liquid, safe, limited supply asset that stores value and serves as central pillar of a new crypto market destined to rise tremendously, we would get a “gold standard” price. Using the same pricing as above for gold and using the maximum possible btc supply, we would get the following conservative estimates:

3500 billion / 21 million = 167 000$ (using M1).

13000 billion / 21 million = 619 000$ (using M2).

Using the same average price as we got for gold (approx), we get 393 000$, so roughly 400 000$.

This evaluation underestimates the potential price with this method, because btc has a fixed maximum limit, and usd money supply is always increasing, and all this is typically at least a bit priced into market prices at any given time. This valuation seems on the high side to me, but I can’t really say it’s necessarily wrong.

Conclusion

One possible scenario is that all governments eliminate the fiat currency system, take on a national crypto currency system, and ban btc and most other cryptos. Knowing how slow large states move and how inefficient are, and seeing how btc and the others are gaining market momentum, I see this as low probability for the coming few years.

Given this, there are a few potential scenarios to ponder:

  1. A general selloff of all cryptos, crashing the price to zero.
  2. A general selloff of btc to go towards other cryptos, thus crashing the price of btc. Not likely due to the “leader advantage”, convertibility to usd, and widespread and growing use of btc.
  3. 1% of global wealth parks in cryptos and 50% of that goes to btc, giving a price of 74k usd as a conservative lower bound.
  4. 2% of global wealth parks in cryptos and 50% of that goes to btc, giving a price of 148k usd.
  5. 3% of global wealth parks in cryptos and 50% of that goes to btc, giving a price of 222k usd.
  6. 4% of global wealth parks in cryptos and 50% of that goes to btc, giving a price of 296k usd.
  7. 5% of global wealth parks in cryptos and 50% of that goes to btc, giving a price of 370k usd.
  8. The price of btc becomes similar to the price of gold due to “reference and refuge currency” status, giving an approximate price of 400k usd.

What to make of all this? Well, if I disregard my analysis, I find prices of 74k+ usd per btc totally unrealistic! But at the same time, the general logic is there and I have yet to get one logic-based explanation of why it “should” be otherwise. I don’t know what to say… If the market holds and crypto/blockchain technology rises as an important new building block for the economy of the future, it is indeed quite possible to see btc prices hover well above 100k, with even more stratospheric potential. Again, this is based on assumptions. If these assumptions hold, 100k+ usd per btc is strangely a “realistic” pricing… I know it seems weird… I feel the same way! Clap, like, share, and comment! And please read Part I!

Feel free to send questions or comments to me by email. Regards.

Pascal Bedard

pbedard@yourpersonaleconomist.com

title: The Bitcoin Bubble II: Pricing BTC
content_html:
The Bitcoin Bubble II: Pricing BTC

Pascal Bedard
Dec 9, 2017

In my post “The Bitcoin Bubble” I explain the logic behind pricing btc relative to the usd. That post created quite a stir, with some people sending me mails to either tell me I’m crazy OR to tell me “it all makes sense” even if the 100k usd per btc seems ridiculous (even to me!). Please take the time to read in full that post, as it is the back bone and starting point for this one and provides the necessary discussion and caveats. Btc could be “as good as gold” which could bring it to as much as half a million OR, even without “gold status”, it could move quite easily to close to 100k usd… read on for details…

Again, “opinions” don’t matter, including my own. What matters to make sense of the crypto phenomenon is to at least have some kind of logical framework to evaluate the prices of cryptos between them and relative to standard currencies such as the usd or cad.

Lets look at various scenarios to add to the framework of btc valuation as we started doing in the initial post, and add a more explicit discussion about the risks to these scenarios, as well as more precise calculations.

Valuation of assets in uncharted territory

First lets state the obvious: we don’t know how to value cryptos, because it’s totally uncharted territory, they do not pertain to a “piece of property” of capital like stock nor are they a claim on future income in the form of debt, such as corporate or government bonds or mortgage debt.

A typical valuation for a company might look at future possible profits, which would include scale possibilities, competition, how “fundamental” the new company is in terms of innovation and new products that “change the game” and the genius of the management and the strategic position now and going forward of the company and its products. A few examples of companies that came up with “game changers” are Ford’s Model T, Microsoft’s “Windows”, Apple’s Iphone and MacBook, Facebook, Uber, Netflix, and AirBnB. The list is extremely long — we could write a book only on this fascinating subject.

For debt pricing, the interest rate is related to the relative availability of credit in the market (if available loanable funds are scarce, there is more “fighting for credit” between credit demanders) and competition in the credit supplier market (if I am the only one supplying credit, I can charge you a very high interest rate).

On top of these basic valuation considerations, there are risks to consider. For instance, inflation takes away purchasing power of nominal amounts of money received in the future. You might also never see your money again, because of defaults or bankruptcies. If you put your money in other currencies, you are also exposed to “exchange rate risk”: I put 100 usd in Japan for investments, and the Yen crashes relative to the usd, which means whatever Yen I have are worth less than before when expressed in usd.

How could we put a “value” on crypto currencies? The only reasonable way to do this is to “guesstimate” how much money (expressed in usd) parked in OTHER asset classes will flock TO cryptos in general. Then you add details crypto by crypto.

But as I explain in my initial post, btc is “special” in this matter, because it has the leader advantage, and THAT has made it the most easily and widely convertible to usd, the most trusted and traded, and THAT is absolutely fundamental to the entire project. This has positioned btc as the “central pillar” of the entire crypto world, because OTHER cryptos are generally convertible to btc, and btc is convertible to usd.

For example, I personally think “eth” (Ether, associated to the Ethereum blockchain) has considerably more usability, scalability, and innovative potential for society as whole, as is also the case for Ripple and a few others.

But “usefulness” is NOT a core building block of a good store of value… a good store of value must not degrade, must have limited supply, and be readily convertible to a very useful currency (typically the usd). That is the central difference between btc and most others: btc is readily convertible to usd. The second most “easily convertible” crypto directly to usd is Ethereum, and indeed it also has a solid pricing, but nothing near btc valuation.

Before we continue, here are the top 10 cryptos and their approximate respective market shares in % of the approximately 415 billion dollar market capitalization of the total crypto currency market:

Bitcoin (btc), 60%

Ethereum (eth), 10%

Bitcoin Cash (bch), 5%

Iota (miota), 3%

Ripple (xrp), 3%

Litecoin (ltc), 2%

Dash (dash), 1%

Nem (xem), 1%

Monero (xmr), 1%

Bitcoin Gold (btg), 1%

Using conservative estimates, total crypto market value is about 415 billion, while total value of stocks + bonds + gold is about 180 trillion, and that is a VERY conservative estimate. This means official asset classes (not counting real estate, land, art, silver, and a few others) is a bit more than 400 times bigger than the entire crypto market. As I explain in my first post on this Bitcoin thing, I think the best way to estimate pricing of cryptos is to get an idea of how much money wants to “park” in crypto assets in general, then in each crypto currency specifically.

Scenarios and Risks for Pricing the Bitcoin

Scenario 0$

It is possible that the value of btc plunges to zero (or close to zero) at one point. As far as I can tell, the possible causes of btc crashing to zero would be:

  1. Widespread fraud that causes a breach in the “trustability” of the btc and associated blockchain, and more importantly the players in the market, like the major exchanges and so on. Fraud can come from several sources, but mostly 3 main sources: 1) hackings that gain access to the “private keys” of holders of btc and other cryptos, which enables the hackers to send the hacked btc content associated to those wallets to themselves, then selling off the whole thing against usd and walking away with a good loot. This has happened on several occasions but still remains rare relative to the size of the market. The second potential cause for total collapse is 2) fraud coming from “crypto brokers” such as Coinbase, with too many bad experiences, bad customer service, or outright theft, causing a breakdown of trust. This has not yet happened on a broad scale, although customer service and transparency are indeed left wanting in this sphere for now. The third major potential cause for crypto fraud is 3) “fake cryptos” on parallel blockchains that pretend to be the btc blockchain and somehow get enough collaborators to make people confused about what is a true btc and what is a “counterfeit” btc. In ALL cases, the ultimate killer is a breakdown of trust. I do not see this as a high probability outcome, but it is a possible outcome nonetheless.
  2. Concerted and generalized war on btc and other cryptos by major states. This would happen due to difficulty of regulation and other blockchain and crypto control issues. Not just China, but ALL major countries, and especially the USA. This would cause a fracture of one essential item making btc an interesting asset for the foreseeable future and giving it the “gold standard” position within the rising crypto world: convertibility to usd. If convertibility to usd is lost, the value of most cryptos will fall to close to zero, because more than 99%+ of “real world transactions” are in standard currencies, and convertibility to usd and/or major currencies is key to any asset class. I also do not see this as a high probability outcome, because there are growing numbers of institutional players, futures markets and btc derivatives, and organized and regulated exchanges that deal with cryptos (especially btc), along with some transactions being done in the various cryptos.
  3. A major selloff by initial holders. This could cause the price to crash due to the relatively shallow depth of the btc market (it does not take “that much” sell or buy activity to move the price, compared to major currencies or major bond markets, for example). A big selloff is possible, but I am not sure this is high probability, because why sell all your high-value assets that are gaining value and are a great store of value? In fact, it is mostly the 2 other points above that would trigger this 3rd one, and I do not see this as a probable outcome. This does not mean initial holders of btc won’t sell some of their assets to get income… but that is a manageable “mini shock” for btc.

Btc currently has almost 400 000 transactions per day (and growing rapidly), has growing government regulation (hence acceptance), has rapidly growing interest by “Big Money” such as banks, hedge funds, and major fund managers, is solving scalability problems a bit more every passing week, and now has official futures trading by big institutional players. Criminal money in btc is losing importance relative to “legal” money. The Ethereum blockchain handles MORE transactions per day than btc and has a LOT of “real world potential”, as does Ripple, whose technology was recently adopted by giants like American Express and Santander. Does this sound like cryptos and blockchains are a passing fad that will all just go away any time soon? No.

Given the facts, I will thus posit for the remainder of this text that 1) cryptos are there to stay and 2) btc has a leader advantage, simply because it was the first and is the most easily and widely convertible to major currencies.

Scenario 1000$

One possibility for the price of btc is that it attracted a disproportionate amount of interest relative to its true usefulness and intrinsic value. This would suggest that the “number 2 crypto currency” has a more realistic pricing, which is the price of Ethereum, roughly 600$-700$ (the current price). Given that eth may be underpriced and btc may be overpriced (I am not saying this is the case), we would have a price for Ethereum of at least 1000$.

That would imply that 1) the net influx of capital flocking FROM standard asset classes like stocks and bonds TO crypto assets would all go to non-btc cryptos AND 2) currently parked funds in btc would go towards the other crypto assets, thus causing a general upward shift of non-btc prices such as Ethereum and a severe downward shift of btc.

This would be a 95% price drop. This would cause general panic about crypto assets and a widespread run for the exits regarding that asset class, perhaps crashing the price towards zero, at least for a while.

To me, this is the highest risk scenario on btc in terms of its probability of occurrence: 1) a widespread selloff of btc to buy other cryptos and 2) all new “outside money” (from more classic asset classes) going TO cryptos to be concentrated in non-btc assets such as Ethereum. This is possible, but I doubt it is likely to happen as long as the social norm of btc being the “central pillar” of cryptos for liquidity and convertibility remains intact.

Scenario 74 000$

A more realistic estimation of global wealth currently parked in non-crypto assets includes all of the following:

  1. Stocks: 100 trillion.
  2. Credit and related markets: 150 trillion.
  3. Gold and silver: 10 trillion.
  4. Undeclared criminal wealth: 4 trillion.

Lets just take a round number of 250 trillion to base our calculations.

Current usd value of btc is about 250 billion, which is 0,1% of the total estimation for the major asset classes (250 trillion). We thus currently have about 0.1% of global wealth parked in btc, and a bit less than 0.2% of global wealth parked all crypto currencies combined.

A total selloff of the top 10 cryptos is unlikely for now and for the foreseeable future (unless one of the main risks materialize), because the emergence of cryptos and blockchain is a bit like the emergence of Internet in the 1990s: even with the “dot com crash” of the early 2000s, you did not have an overnight abandonment of all Internet and the Web. It’s “structural” and not related to corporate profits or even the economic outlook, which can change dramatically within one year when a crisis hits.

Based on this and seeing growing interest and momentum of cryptos and blochchain,it seems possible that 1% of all global wealth could eventually flock to cryptos, especially with currently high asset prices and low expected returns… If we suppose that btc share of cryptos falls from 60% to 50% and the other 10% is gained by others, we would have 50% of 1% of total world wealth going towards btc in the next few years. Since current and near-future btc global supply is about 17 million (the maximum is 21 million but will not be reached for a while), we get the following valuation, for 50% of 1% of total wealth flocking to 17 million btc:

0.5*0.01*250 trillion / 17 million = 74 000$ (approx).

Note that there seems to me a great deal of demand for assets available to park wealth, with real estate markets becoming more and more like stock markets and Asian savings seeking to park in safe assets. Given this, the estimate of global wealth looking for a place to park is probably severely underestimated at 250 trillion, so 74k usd per btc is very conservative.

Scenario 148 000$ and 370 000$

This is the very same story as the preceding one, but with 2% and 5% respectively of global wealth going to crypto assets.

Scenario “as good as gold” 400 000$

There are about 6 billion ounces of gold in circulation. M1 usd money supply is about 3500 billion usd, M2 usd money supply is about 13 000 billion. Based on these 2 most-common and referenced money supply measures and using a naïve (and somewhat over simplified) extrapolation, the price of gold “should” be:

3500/6 = 583 usd (using M1).

13000/6 = 2167 usd (using M2).

The current price of gold is roughly 1300 usd, so the price is between the M1 and M2 implied prices, since the average of the 2 prices is 1375$.

Supposing btc gains traction as a legal, liquid, safe, limited supply asset that stores value and serves as central pillar of a new crypto market destined to rise tremendously, we would get a “gold standard” price. Using the same pricing as above for gold and using the maximum possible btc supply, we would get the following conservative estimates:

3500 billion / 21 million = 167 000$ (using M1).

13000 billion / 21 million = 619 000$ (using M2).

Using the same average price as we got for gold (approx), we get 393 000$, so roughly 400 000$.

This evaluation underestimates the potential price with this method, because btc has a fixed maximum limit, and usd money supply is always increasing, and all this is typically at least a bit priced into market prices at any given time. This valuation seems on the high side to me, but I can’t really say it’s necessarily wrong.

Conclusion

One possible scenario is that all governments eliminate the fiat currency system, take on a national crypto currency system, and ban btc and most other cryptos. Knowing how slow large states move and how inefficient are, and seeing how btc and the others are gaining market momentum, I see this as low probability for the coming few years.

Given this, there are a few potential scenarios to ponder:

  1. A general selloff of all cryptos, crashing the price to zero.
  2. A general selloff of btc to go towards other cryptos, thus crashing the price of btc. Not likely due to the “leader advantage”, convertibility to usd, and widespread and growing use of btc.
  3. 1% of global wealth parks in cryptos and 50% of that goes to btc, giving a price of 74k usd as a conservative lower bound.
  4. 2% of global wealth parks in cryptos and 50% of that goes to btc, giving a price of 148k usd.
  5. 3% of global wealth parks in cryptos and 50% of that goes to btc, giving a price of 222k usd.
  6. 4% of global wealth parks in cryptos and 50% of that goes to btc, giving a price of 296k usd.
  7. 5% of global wealth parks in cryptos and 50% of that goes to btc, giving a price of 370k usd.
  8. The price of btc becomes similar to the price of gold due to “reference and refuge currency” status, giving an approximate price of 400k usd.

What to make of all this? Well, if I disregard my analysis, I find prices of 74k+ usd per btc totally unrealistic! But at the same time, the general logic is there and I have yet to get one logic-based explanation of why it “should” be otherwise. I don’t know what to say… If the market holds and crypto/blockchain technology rises as an important new building block for the economy of the future, it is indeed quite possible to see btc prices hover well above 100k, with even more stratospheric potential. Again, this is based on assumptions. If these assumptions hold, 100k+ usd per btc is strangely a “realistic” pricing… I know it seems weird… I feel the same way! Clap, like, share, and comment! And please read Part I!

Feel free to send questions or comments to me by email. Regards.

Pascal Bedard

pbedard@yourpersonaleconomist.com
